main_question:
PUBLISHER* [After reviewing briefly the greatly changed conditions in the publication of college text-books which have been brought about in the last forty years the speaker proceeded:] The point of these observations bearing on this subject is that conditions between authors or editors and publishers of literary texts have changed materially since the days when but a few pages of notes made up, together with the original text, or a portion of it, a textbook for school and college use. [masked sentence revising an implied expectation] In the way of progressive development of these modern language text books, after the notes, came vocabularies.

answer_strings: Yet, as regards the remuneration of the author or editor, despite these changed conditions, the conventional ten per cent royalty contract has remained in statu quo.
Yet, as regards the remuneration of the author or editor, despite these changed conditions, the conventional ten per cent royalty contract has evolved.
At present, however, a text with notes is more in demand by the school public than the same without notes; a text with a vocabulary is a favorite compared with one without a vocabulary.

to maintain the book's commercial viability and meet distribution deadlines

even when the cover is plain, the internal layout betrays the publisher

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Author vs. Publisher, a novel published in 0 by James Geddes, an US .
main_question:
Recently when giving to one of the book firms an order for some thirty odd copies of a most admirable book on the Great War (a text-book of some 250 pages, con- cvi taining prefatory matter, more than thirty very fine engravings, notes and vocabulary, published in 1920), the reply from the publisher came back as follows: "Thank you for your letter and friendly comment on 'So-and-So' book on the War. I regret that what you say partakes of the nature of a postmortem eulogy; [masked clause revising an implied expectation]. This book comes in that class, due largely to the fact, I imagine, that teachers seem to be inclined to forget the War and all connected with it, and books of stories about the War are not generally acceptable."

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause revising an implied expectation]:
answer_strings: but the present conditions have made it necessary that we should trim our list of all books which were not meeting with a certain minimum sale

that the book is still available
that it will be perceived as a critical, historical analysis rather than a nostalgic eulogy

If possible, the publisher is even more anxious to sell the book than the civ author is, for the former's money is locked up in it.

but because he has no choice
that delays are solely production‑related

If possible, the publisher is even more anxious to sell the book than the civ author is, for the former's money is locked up in it.

the manuscript stayed shelved, unclaimed forever

main_question:
(2) Because a publishing firm asks him to do a piece of workwithout which request he might never have done it. (3) Because the editor of a Series asks him to contribute to the Series, the destinies of which the editor controls. metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Author vs. Publisher, a novel published in 0 by James Geddes, an US .
main_question:
As a matter of fact, the publishing contract between you and us establishes your rights fully. We cannot see where there is the slightest advantage to you in retaining the copyright, or the slightest disadvantage to you in assigning it. I have every wish to avoid saying anything that may seem in the slightest degree unpleasant, [masked clause revising an implied expectation]

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause revising an implied expectation]:
answer_strings: but I am obliged to say that we have called upon you for a document which we have a right to ask for and which you are under obligation to give us."
but I regret to say that you have not been asked  for a document which we have no right to demand, nor are you bound to provide it
but representing an immense amount of labor on the part of authors and of expense on the part of the publishers, that might be expended in a manner more worth while
but the present conditions have made it necessary that we should trim our list of all books which were not meeting with a certain minimum sale
but I must point out that keeping the copyright does not align with your best interests

notwithstanding the foregoing, the publisher shall pay the author a royalty of 15 % of net sales, payable quarterly, and shall provide the author with a detailed statement of account within 30 days of each payment

We cannot see where there is the slightest advantage to you in retaining the copyright, or the slightest disadvantage to you in assigning it.
